content: The "Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998" allows for licensing federally owned inventions under cooperative research and development agreements. The "Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998" allows federal agencies to grant exclusive or partially exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions under certain conditions to promote their utilization by the public. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows federal agencies to grant exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions under certain conditions to promote public utilization. Applicants must commit to practical utilization within a reasonable time, ensure competition is not lessened, and comply with antitrust laws. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows federal agencies to grant exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions under certain conditions to promote public utilization. Licenses require products to be manufactured in the United States and give preference to small businesses for practical application within a reasonable time. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows federal agencies to grant exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions with specific terms and conditions. These include retaining a license for the government, requiring utilization reporting by the licensee, and empowering the agency to terminate the license if terms are not met. The Technology Transfer Commercialization Act of 1998 allows federal agencies to grant exclusive licenses on federally owned inventions with specific terms and conditions. The agency can terminate the license if the licensee fails to achieve practical utilization of the invention, breaches an agreement, or if termination is necessary to meet public use requirements specified by federal regulations. No exclusive or partially exclusive license may be granted under section 207(a)(2) unless public notice of the intention to grant the license has been provided at least 15 days before the grant, and all comments received have been considered. This does not apply to licenses for inventions made under cooperative research. The licensing of inventions made under a cooperative research and development agreement must include a plan for development and marketing. Federal agencies cannot grant a license without this plan, which is considered privileged and confidential information. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 18 of title 35, United States Code. Technical amendments to Bayh-Dole Act include licensing federally owned inventions. Chapter 18 of title 35, United States Code, also known as the Bayh-Dole Act, is amended to allow Federal agencies employing coinventors to license or acquire rights in inventions made with nonprofit organizations or small business firms. The Bayh-Dole Act is amended to allow Federal agencies to acquire rights in inventions made with nonprofit organizations or small business firms, including acquiring rights for the Federal Government in any invention voluntarily entered into by the party. Technical amendments are made to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980. Amendments to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 include changes to sections 4, 5, 9, and 11. Key revisions involve updating references from sections 6 and 8 to sections 7 and 9, as well as clarifying language regarding State or local governments. Amendments to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 involve changes to sections 11, 14, and 22. Key revisions include updating language and clarifying rights assignment to the United States. Amendments to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 involve updating language in section 22 by changing references from "sections 11, 12, and 13" to "sections 12, 13, and 14". SEC. 6. REVIEW OF COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT PROCEDURES. Each Federal agency with a Federally funded laboratory must report on their policies for gathering and considering views of other agencies on joint work statements or cooperative research agreements. The Committee on National Security of the National Science and Technology Council, along with relevant Federal agencies and national laboratories, will assess existing procedures for interagency coordination regarding major cooperative research agreements involving critical national security technology or competitiveness. Specific criteria will be established to indicate the necessity for such agreements. Procedures will be established to gather and consider agency views on joint work statements and cooperative research and development agreements. The goal is to use existing procedures, minimize burdens on Federal agencies, promote partnerships with national laboratories, and expedite the approval process. The Act establishes procedures for agency views on joint work statements and cooperative research agreements. It does not grant authority to disapprove agreements to certain federal agencies. SEC. 7 of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to allow increased flexibility for federal laboratory partnership intermediaries by including institutions of higher education and educational institutions within the meaning of specific codes. SEC. 8 calls for a study and report on biological deposits in support of biotechnology patents. The General Accounting Office, in consultation with the US Patent and Trademark Office, will conduct a study on risks to the biotechnology industry related to biological deposits for patents. The study will examine export and third-party transfer risks, changes to publication requirements, legal and regulatory comparisons, and provide recommendations. The US Patent and Trademark Office will consider recommendations from a study on risks related to biological deposits for patents. SEC. 9. PROVISIONAL APPLICATIONS. Amendment to provisional application abandonment rules under title 35, United States Code. Provisional applications may be treated as filed under subsection (a) upon request, otherwise considered abandoned after 12 months. Technical amendment regarding weekends and holidays for the 12-month deadline. The period of pendency of provisional applications in the District of Columbia will be extended to the next succeeding secular or business day. The amendments apply to provisional applications filed on or after June 8, 1995. Passed the House of Representatives on October 20, 1998.
